description.narrative: Space cooling is increasingly recognized as a development priority especially in emerging economies located in the tropical climate zone. India is experiencing a rapid growth in demand for space cooling, driven by population growth, urbanization, increasing incomes and rising urban heat. According to the India Cooling Action Plan, space cooling demand in India is expected to rise by 11 times from the year 2018 to the year 2038, leading to energy consumption and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions rising by 4x. The commercial real estate sector is expected to add 100 million RT in capacity during this period. The Company will pioneer the development of DC solutions at scale in India. These projects are expected to improve access to space cooling, reduce lifecycle cooling costs, decrease energy consumption, reduce peak power and refrigerant demand. The energy efficiency benefits are expected to lead to GHG emissions savings. IFC anticipates that the Company would contribute to faster market adoption of DC technology in the Asian countries by successfully demonstrating the commercial viability of the "cooling as a service" business model.

The proposed investment is an equity investment of US$25 million by IFC for a 25% stake in a District Cooling Company (DCC or the Company), proposed to be set up in Singapore along with the National Central Cooling Company PJSC (Tabreed or Sponsor). Tabreed will hold 75% stake in the Company. The DCC will enter into long term concession agreements with major real estate developers to deploy district cooling (DC) technology in commercial, industrial, and retail establishments in India and other markets in Asia to deploy around 90,000 refrigeration tons (RT) of cooling capacity in the next 3-4 years.
